title: Wisdom for Life
shortSummary: Proverbs 22 offers practical wisdom on character, relationships, and godly living. It emphasizes the value of a good name, humility, prudent behavior, and the importance of training children in the fear of the Lord. The chapter also warns against folly, oppression, and unwise associations, highlighting the blessings of generosity and diligence.
timeline: c. 10th century BC - Solomon's Proverbs collection

keyCharacters.name: The Wise Teacher
keyCharacters.description: The primary voice in Proverbs, traditionally attributed to Solomon, who imparts practical and spiritual wisdom throughout the chapter.

keyCharacters.name: The Simple
keyCharacters.description: Individuals lacking prudence and understanding, who are warned about the consequences of ignoring wisdom.

keyCharacters.name: The Rich and the Poor
keyCharacters.description: Represent social classes referenced to teach about God's sovereignty and the dangers of wealth and poverty in relation to power and dependence.

definitions.definition: Stubbornly contrary or perverse in behavior, leading to trouble and snares.
A symbol of discipline used to guide and correct children, representing parental authority and instruction.
A person who mocks or derides others, causing strife and contention.
A person who guarantees another's debt or obligation, risking personal loss.

outline.heading: The Value of a Good Name and Prudence
outline.description: This section stresses the superiority of a good reputation over wealth, the equality of all before God, and the importance of foresight and humility as foundations for a blessed life.

outline.heading: Instruction for Child Training and Social Realities
outline.description: Wisdom is given on raising children in the fear of the Lord, the dynamics of wealth and debt, and the blessing that comes from generosity toward the poor.

outline.heading: Dealing with Opposition and Pursuing Purity
outline.description: Advice is given to remove those who cause strife, to value purity of heart, and to discipline foolishness early to avoid future harm.

outline.heading: Listening to Wisdom and Justice
outline.description: The chapter calls for attentive listening to wise counsel, warns against oppressing the poor, and assures divine justice for the afflicted.

outline.heading: Avoiding Harmful Associations and Financial Entanglements
outline.description: Believers are cautioned to avoid friendships with angry people and to be careful about financial guarantees that could lead to personal loss.

outline.heading: Respecting Heritage and Diligence
outline.description: The final verses encourage honoring ancestral boundaries and commend diligence in work as a path to honor and influence.

application: Cultivate a good reputation by living with integrity and humility, valuing God's approval above material wealth.
Train children consistently in the fear of the Lord, using loving discipline to guide them away from folly.
Practice generosity toward the poor as a reflection of God's heart and a source of blessing.
Avoid close relationships with those who display anger or contentious behavior to protect your spiritual well-being.

keyVerses.text: A good name is rather to be chosen than great riches, and loving favour rather than silver and gold.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the supreme value of character and reputation over material wealth.

keyVerses.text: Train up a child in the way he should go: and when he is old, he will not depart from it.
keyVerses.significance: It underscores the lifelong impact of early spiritual and moral instruction.

keyVerses.text: Rob not the poor, because he is poor: neither oppress the afflicted in the gate: For the LORD will plead their cause, and spoil the soul of those that spoiled them.

keyVerses.text: Seest thou a man diligent in his business? he shall stand before kings; he shall not stand before mean men.
keyVerses.significance: This verse encourages diligence and excellence as a means to gain honor and influence.
